We have conducted extensive experiments under different compression levels: C​R=0.1𝐶𝑅0.1CR=0.1 and C​R=0.01𝐶𝑅0.01CR=0.01 and degrees of data heterogeneity: β=0.1𝛽0.1\beta=0.1 and β=0.5𝛽0.5\beta=0.5.
The final model’s test accuracy of our proposed BCRS and OPWA algorithms, alongside the baselines FedAvg, TOPK, and EFTOPK, across various datasets, are summarized in Table 2.

S5.T3.caption: Table 3. Communication time (second) to reach the target accuracy (40%) on CIFAR-10 under β=0.1𝛽0.1\beta=0.1. Blanks carry no meaning in the context of our experiments.
S5.T3.table:
Algorithm CIFAR-10(40%)
Actual Time Max Time Min Time
FedAvg CR=0.1 3677.238 3677.238 104.514
CR=0.01 3677.238 3677.238 104.514
TOPK CR=0.1 281.364 1386.653 28.317
CR=0.01 86.985 3634.929 74.482
EFTOPK CR=0.1 157.412 1521.802 31.073
CR=0.01 52.062 3719.547 76.245
BCRS CR=0.1 17.938 – –

references:
Communication Efficiency. In evaluating the communication efficiency of both baselines and BCRS, we record the time to reach target accuracy for each algorithm on CIFAR-10 as illustrated in Table 3. It can be observed that there’s a huge difference between the accumulated M​i​n​T​i​m​e𝑀𝑖𝑛𝑇𝑖𝑚𝑒MinTime and M​a​x​T​i​m​e𝑀𝑎𝑥𝑇𝑖𝑚𝑒MaxTime, highlighting the need to mitigate the straggler problem. To achieve 40% accuracy, FedAvg, as a standard baseline, required approximately 3677.238 seconds to reach this accuracy level. Under C​R=0.1𝐶𝑅0.1CR=0.1, the TOPK and EFTOPK algorithms demonstrated comparable efficiency, taking about 281.364 seconds and 157.412 seconds, respectively. In stark contrast, our BCRS algorithm significantly improves performance efficiency, achieving the target accuracy in just 17.938 seconds, much faster than the baselines.
Fig. 6 displays the breakdown of each process in one FL round and our BCRS algorithm effectively mitigates the communication overhead.
To clarify, blanks in Table 3 do not mean missing experiments but indicate instances that are not applicable to the experiments. Blanks in the M​a​x​T​i​m​e𝑀𝑎𝑥𝑇𝑖𝑚𝑒MaxTime and M​i​n​T​i​m​e𝑀𝑖𝑛𝑇𝑖𝑚𝑒MinTime columns for BCRS indicate non-applicability since the BCRS algorithm is designed to equalize client communication time. Therefore, specific maximum and minimum time measurements are not meaningful and thus omitted from Table 3.

It is imperative to underscore that the evaluation of all algorithms was simulated under random bandwidth and latency conditions. It is advisable to draw comparisons between the recorded Compressed Time and the corresponding accumulated Maximum time and Minimum time for each algorithm. Table 3 also reflects an intriguing balance between communication overhead and convergence rate. Employing a compression ratio does not directly translate to a proportional acceleration in the convergence rate. This finding further indicates the BCRS algorithm’s significant advantage in both ensuring accuracy and reducing the communication overhead.
Figure 10 illustrates the relationship between accuracy and accumulated communication time under various settings. Notably, our BCRS algorithm demonstrates superior performance, achieving high accuracy with significantly reduced accumulated communication time compared to FedAvg and other baseline methods.

references: In evaluating our OPWA algorithm, the focus is on the significant role played by the parameter enlarge rate γ𝛾\gamma. We explore a range of γ𝛾\gamma values, from 1 up to the total number of clients (N𝑁N), to gauge their effect on the algorithm’s performance. The training curves for OPWA with different γ𝛾\gamma configurations are shown in Figure. 11. We observe that the optimal γ𝛾\gamma value is not necessarily within a certain candidate range. To better illustrate this observation, we select three representing values of γ𝛾\gamma, i.e. γ=3,5,7𝛾357\gamma=3,5,7, and summarize the recorded accuracies and FedAvg’s accuracy in Table 4.

Optimal γ𝛾\gamma selection. We can observe in Table 4 that the optimal enlarge rate γ𝛾\gamma is not confined to the range [1, |St|subscript𝑆𝑡\left|S_{t}\right|] (which corresponds to the number of clients selected). When the best value of γ𝛾\gamma falls in [111, |St|subscript𝑆𝑡\left|S_{t}\right|], we interpret it as the scenario where the updates of parameters with a low degree of overlap are insufficient due to the averaging process. On the other hand, the best enlarge rate γ𝛾\gamma falling in the range [|St|+1subscript𝑆𝑡1\left|S_{t}\right|+1, N𝑁N] is intriguing. It may suggest a balance between finding γ𝛾\gamma and the optimal server learning rate α𝛼\alpha and the learning rate η𝜂\eta. In this context, the larger enlarge rates compensate for α𝛼\alpha and η𝜂\eta that are not perfectly tuned for the FL environment.
